article:
The 'Bunsen solubility coefficient' or 'Bunsen absorption coefficient' (Î±),
named for Robert Bunsen, is one of a number of units used to describe the
solubility of gases in liquids. It is frequently used in physiology.

The Bunsen coefficient is defined as the volume of gas, reduced to 273.15 K (0
Â°C) and 101.3 kPa, which is absorbed (under equilibrium) per unit volume of a
pure liquid solvent at a specified temperature, under the partial pressure of
the gas of 101.3 kPa. P.G.T. Fogg and W. Gerrard, "Solubility of Gases in
Liquids. A Critical Evaluation of Gas/Liquid System in Theory and Practice."
John Wiley & Sons, 1991. ISBN 0 471 9225 5.

The units of volume are unimportant as long as they are the same, but often
cm 3 are used. In the SI system, the Bunsen coefficient is dimensionless. IUPAC-
NIST Solubility Database, NIST Standard Reference Database 106, Introduction.
http://srdata.nist.gov/solubility/intro.aspx
